claim: The market does not reward 'better'; it rewards 'different.' Being 'the best' at something generic is strategically impotent because it implies occupying the same position as competitors. Only is better than best.
rationale: Being 'the best' at a generic offering leads to 'the same, only a little bit more.' A good strategy means being 'the only' brand offering a specific value, preventing 'better' strategies disguised as 'only' ones. This creates uncontested market space.

claim: Test your strategy with the 'opposites game': ask if the opposite would also make logical sense. If yes, it's likely a good strategy. If no, it's a strategy everyone would agree with—therefore illegitimate.
rationale: A law firm with 'winning the most cases' fails because its opposite (trying to lose) is nonsensical. Good value-based strategies offer strong alternatives to other legitimate market offers, meaning competitors might rationally choose not to do what you do.

claim: Remove all subjective language from your strategy and see what remains. Words like 'good,' 'great,' 'world-class,' or 'best' are filler disguising the absence of strong thought. If unexplainable without them, it's not a strategy.
rationale: Subjective language isn't specific or directional—it merely states a desired reaction. It also signals a 'better' strategy rather than a truly different one. Your job is to offer something specific; subjective judgments belong to the market.

claim: Use the 'how cascade': repeatedly ask 'How?' until the answer is a solution, not just an aspiration. The point where a goal becomes a strategy is when a solution is proposed, provoking 'Ah, OK, got it.'
rationale: Many brands confuse goals with strategy, leading to vague statements like 'double our turnover.' A strategy should provoke clarity, allowing others to start filling in executional blanks, not leave them more confused.

claim: Match strategy sophistication to category interest level. Low-interest categories (toilet paper, accountancy) require blunt, visceral value offerings. High-interest categories (fashion, cars) allow for sophisticated, rich strategies.
rationale: Consumers buy low-interest products on 'zombie-auto-pilot' with minimal attention. Burdening them with overly lofty strategy causes messages to fly over their heads. You can't make a brand absolutely interesting if its category isn't.

claim: Clustering leads to commodification: when businesses mirror each other's innovations and prices, they become more alike, forcing cost cuts and increased spend that hammer profit margins.
rationale: The US airline industry in the 1990s exemplifies clustering—carriers relentlessly competed for business travelers, leading to widespread bankruptcy. Effective strategy aims for non-competition by opening new market space instead of closing it.

claim: Businesses convince themselves they are executing strategy when they aren't. A strategy only exists if it can be perceived from the outside. If you have to 'make the case' for your strategy, it's not obvious enough.
rationale: Iconic brands like Apple and Tesla have strategies that are externally obvious; consumers can intuit their strategy without any messaging. The strategy must be big, binary, and 'in your face' to produce significant results.

claim: The 'challenger trap': copying iconic challenger brands from the past (Ben & Jerry's, Patagonia, Innocent) means fighting the status quo with the status quo. Those brands now represent category norms, not disruption.
rationale: Innocent, once revolutionary for health and ethics in juice, now operates values standard across supermarkets. True challengers must challenge the status quo as it is right now, finding new territory where established brands are weak or silent.

claim: Self-loathing businesses fail when founders dislike what their business is naturally becoming and try to transition into something 'groovier' that doesn't match its inherent nature. Company versus management: company wins every time.
rationale: Effective strategy emerges from observing how a prototype evolves organically in the market, then accelerating in that natural direction. Trying to 'change' a business from one thing to another often fails. Focus and intensify the direction it's already leaning.

claim: Contrarian value breaks explicit category rules by being 'bad' at what the category values most. This is nearly impossible for competitors to copy because it would undermine their own offerings.
rationale: Nintendo Switch drastically underperformed on console power to produce a smaller, lighter machine playable handheld. Southwest couldn't be copied by American or United because their strategy required sacrificing business travelers—competitors' core market.

claim: Context shift unlocks value without changing the product by framing it against a different category or competitors. Value is contextual; an identical brand can perform differently in new environments because relative merits shift.
rationale: A cereal bar, unhealthy within the 'health bar' category, repositioned against confectionery (candy bars). While unhealthy for health bars, it was relatively healthier than candy, and its sugar content became a strength in 'dirty' channels like corner shops.

claim: Cross-category copying: borrow branding elements from brands in totally different categories with similar value offerings. This makes you look entirely different from your category while seeming instantly familiar and 'safe.'
rationale: Domino's branding (bold, simple, corporate) resembles delivery companies (FedEx, UPS), not other pizza brands, because their value is efficient delivery. Tesla presents as a tech brand (Apple-like) because they represent 'high tech' electric power.

claim: Southwest Airlines exemplified declustering by abandoning the lucrative business travel segment entirely to focus on low-cost travelers—an explicitly non-competitive move that led to massive success while other airlines struggled with bankruptcy.
rationale: While US airlines relentlessly competed for business travelers in the 1990s leading to widespread bankruptcy, Southwest's strategy was 'deciding what not to do'—gracefully surrendering parts of the market to create uncontested space.

claim: Nokia abandoned its strong position for robust, cheap phones to copy the iPhone, losing their core market. Apple embraced a small 15% market share but uncontested, achieving 79% profit share through their 'walled garden.'
rationale: Surrendering large, contested space for small, uncontested space creates massive profitability. Nokia's demise is a cautionary tale of abandoning contrarian value to chase a competitor's position instead of defending their own territory.

claim: Method cleaning products introduced 'stylishness' to a category universally sold in ugly packaging, allowing products to be displayed rather than hidden. This gave massive standout and accentuated their eco-credentials—unexpected value in an unexpected category.
rationale: Categories have 'core' value offerings that lead to clustering. Delivering unexpected value involves stepping outside assumptions. Method's stylishness, while unexpected for cleaning products, wasn't random—it supported their eco-credibility.
